publication of statements including statements of opinion in ordinary course of publication of newspaper

trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 4(2). held: (1) publication of statements, including statements of opinion, made in the ordinary course of the publication of a newspaper can constitute misleading and deceptive conduct within the trade practices act 1974 (cth), s. 52. there is no definable boundary between conduct which is misleading or deceptive or likely to mislead or deceive and material which is defamatory; defamatory material does not fall outside the operation of s. 52(1) merely by reason of its being defamatory.

subsisting claim by lessor in supreme court secns 52(1), 53a(1)(b), 82 trade practices act 1974 . trade practices
false or misleading statement concerning lease of shop
supreme court action by lessor for possession, rent and charges

trade practices act 1974 (cth), ss. 52 , 53a, 82 . the applicants sought damages under s. 82 of the trade practices act 1974 from the respondents in respect of alleged breaches of ss. 52 and 53a thereof. in august 1979 the applicants entered into a lease for a three-year term of a shop in a shopping centre from the first respondent. the applicants alleged certain oral statements by a servant of the second respondent, agents for the owners of the centre, made in the course of explaining to them characteristics of the shop and the terms of the proposed lease. by a writ issued out of the supreme court of victoria in may 1980 the first respondent had claimed possession and arrears of rent and other charges. the applicants had surrendered the lease. the respondents filed a joint defence and appeared by the same counsel.
